Working from home has gone from being a growing trend to a full-scale phenomenon. There are many perks to a work-from-home arrangement, to be sure, but there can also be downsides: For example, there’s a good chance you’ll need to supply your own monitor.

Fortunately, there are many great home office monitors to choose from, as I’ve discovered through extensive real-world testing.

Below you’ll find my picks for the best home office monitors, and below that you can learn more about what specs and features matter when shopping for a home office monitor.
title: Best monitors for a home office: 11 top-notch displays that mean business

You’d be surprised by how much extra space you can reclaim just by doing that! But with ultrawide monitors, that’s easier said than done. title: This heavy-duty monitor arm can easily hold huge displays, now 29% off

description:
SSDs, or solid state drives, have drastically improved the computing experience over the last decade or so. Thanks to them, once ponderous boot times now border on instantaneous, programs and games are far more responsive, and the frustratingly long waits to load large files are largely a thing of a past.

So… if you’re not yet using an SSD, what are you waiting for? If you already have an older SSD, you might consider upgrading it for the even headier performance offered by cutting-edge PCIe 4.0 and 5.0 designs. If your PC sports those technologies, of course.

That said, a premium drive may not deliver any more real-world performance than a bargain drive. Mainstream software, including Windows has yet to implement the numerous performance tricks, such as multiple queues, that NVMe SSDs offer.
title: Best SSDs: From SATA to PCIe 5.0, from budget to premium

description:
It’s so easy to love mini PCs these days because they’re powerful yet so tiny and so affordable. Frankly, unless you need the portability of a laptop, your first pick for a home computer should be a mini PC. And here’s one we adore that’s now on sale: the Beelink EQR6 is now $359 on Amazon, a lovely 20% off its original $449 price. That’s very close to the cheapest price it’s ever been, so this is a great deal indeed.

The Beelink EQR6 comes equipped with an AMD Ryzen 7 6800U processor and a chunky 32GB of LPDDR5 RAM, which means this thing is pretty darn performant. description:
It was previously reported by Neowin that uBlock Origin was no longer available for Microsoft’s Edge browser. Following in the footsteps of Google, who killed the uBlock Origin extension on Chrome, it seemed Microsoft had removed the popular ad blocker from Edge’s add-on store.

All of the hubbub surrounding uBlock Origin stems from Google deprecating the Manifest V2 browser extension standard in Chromium. As you may well know, Chrome isn’t the only web browser built on Chromium—in fact, most modern web browsers are, including Edge.

Arlo announced a refresh of its entire home security camera lineup today, unveiling new models in its Essential (HD and 2K resolution), Pro (2K resolution), and Ultra (4K) series.
